applicants: Barkett's Transport (Edms) Bpk t/a Trans SA

sections.facts: The first appellant, a road‑transport company, and its sole shareholder/director (the second appellant) were convicted in the Landdros Court of an offence under s31(1)(a) of the Road Transport Act for transporting 302 cartons of coal on a public road without a valid road‑transport permit. The company had been issued a permit, but the name on the permit was incorrectly recorded as "J Barkett" instead of the correct company name. The lower court held that, because of this description error, the company did not possess a valid permit on the date of the alleged offence and convicted them under s31(1)(a). The appellants appealed, arguing that the correct charge should have been under s31(1)(b) (transport contrary to the terms of a valid permit) and sought an amendment of the charge under s86(1) of the Criminal Procedure Act.
sections.issues: 1) Whether the appellants were correctly charged under s31(1)(a) or whether the proper charge should be s31(1)(b) of the Road Transport Act. 2) Whether s86(1) of the Criminal Procedure Act permits an amendment that substitutes one offence for another, effectively replacing the original charge with a different offence.
sections.principles: The court noted that a valid permit existed despite the clerical error, and under precedent (S v Everson) a permit holder who transports goods not authorised by the permit commits the offence in s31(1)(a). However, later authority (S v Smith) held that s31(1)(a) does not apply where a valid permit exists; the appropriate breach is s31(1)(b). Regarding amendment, the court applied the ordinary meaning of "amend" in s86(1), which allows correction of deficiencies in the charge but not the substitution of a completely different offence. Pre‑cautionary cases (R v Gibson, R v Moyo, R v Nesane, R v Grey) were cited to support that a new offence cannot be introduced by amendment.
sections.application: The court found that the appellants did possess a valid permit at the time of the alleged transport, so the correct charge should have been under s31(1)(b). Nonetheless, because s86(1) does not authorize a replacement of the offence, the State's application to amend the charge from s31(1)(a) to s31(1)(b) was refused. Consequently, the original conviction under s31(1)(a) could not be altered by amendment.
sections.conclusion: The application to amend the charge was dismissed. The appeal was upheld, meaning the original convictions and sentences under s31(1)(a) of the Road Transport Act remain in force.
